L1.brief_rationale: The software layer managing hardware and providing services to applications; universally familiar to anyone who has used a computer through Windows, macOS, or Linux.
The global network connecting billions of devices; universally known and the foundation of modern digital communication.
An organized collection of structured data stored electronically; universally encountered through apps, websites, and business systems.
A set of computers connected to share resources and communicate; familiar to anyone who has used Wi-Fi, Ethernet, or the internet.
Programs and instructions that tell a computer what to do; universally recognized as the complement to hardware in everyday computing.
A malicious program that replicates by inserting itself into other programs; widely known through personal experience with antivirus software and news coverage of cyberattacks.
Delivering computing services over the internet on demand; widely known through consumer services like Google Drive, iCloud, and AWS.
The physical components of a computer such as the CPU, memory, and storage; universally recognized by anyone who has purchased or used a computer.
The method by which data is organized and stored on disk; universally familiar through navigating folders and files on any operating system.
A secret string used to authenticate a user's identity; universally familiar as the most basic form of computer security.
Software with publicly available source code that anyone can inspect and modify; widely known through Linux, Firefox, and the broader free software movement.
Application for accessing and navigating websites on the World Wide Web; universally familiar to all internet users.
The process of finding and fixing errors in software; universally known to anyone who has written even a simple program.

L2.brief_rationale: A database organized into tables with rows and columns related by keys; the dominant database model taught in every undergraduate database course.
The standard language for querying and managing relational databases; learned by virtually every CS undergraduate and widely used across industries.
The foundational protocol suite of the internet defining how data is packaged, addressed, routed, and received; core to every undergraduate networking course.
Systems that track changes to source code over time, exemplified by Git; an essential tool taught to all CS undergraduates for collaborative software development.
A programming paradigm organizing code around objects that bundle data and behavior; the dominant paradigm taught in undergraduate CS through Java, C++, and Python.
An instance of a running program managed by the operating system; a fundamental OS concept covering memory isolation, scheduling, and resource allocation taught in every OS course.
A memory management technique giving each process an idealized address space mapped to physical memory by the OS; a core concept in every undergraduate operating systems course.
Small fast memory located near the processor that stores frequently accessed data to reduce latency; a fundamental computer architecture concept taught at the undergraduate level.
Cryptographic system using a pair of keys (public and private) enabling secure communication without shared secrets; foundational to undergraduate security and networking courses.
The practice of evaluating software to find defects and verify it meets requirements; a core software engineering discipline taught in every undergraduate SE course.
A defined interface allowing software components to communicate with each other; a fundamental software engineering concept encountered in every undergraduate CS program.
A programming paradigm treating computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions, avoiding mutable state; taught in undergraduate PL courses through Haskell, Lisp, or ML.
A network security device that monitors and filters incoming and outgoing traffic based on rules; a fundamental cybersecurity concept taught in undergraduate networking courses.

L3.brief_rationale: Managing multiple computations executing in overlapping time periods; requires working knowledge of threads, synchronization primitives, race conditions, and deadlock avoidance strategies.
A system of networked computers coordinating to achieve a common goal; requires working knowledge of consistency models, fault tolerance, replication, and the challenges of partial failure.
The process of structuring relational database schemas to reduce redundancy and dependency anomalies; requires working knowledge of normal forms (1NF through BCNF) and functional dependencies.

The multi-phase engineering of translating high-level source code into machine code; requires working knowledge of lexical analysis, parsing, semantic analysis, optimization, and code generation pipelines.

The abstract interface between hardware and software defining the machine instructions a processor supports; requires working knowledge of RISC vs. CISC tradeoffs, addressing modes, and pipeline implications.
Packaging software with its dependencies into isolated lightweight units using OS-level virtualization; requires working knowledge of Docker, container orchestration, namespaces, and cgroups.

The hierarchical distributed naming system translating human-readable domain names to IP addresses; requires working knowledge of DNS resolution, record types, caching, and its role in internet infrastructure.
Automatic memory management reclaiming memory no longer in use; requires working knowledge of mark-and-sweep, generational collection, reference counting tradeoffs, and stop-the-world pauses.
Cryptographic protocol providing secure communication over networks; requires working knowledge of the TLS handshake, certificate chains, cipher suites, and how it underpins HTTPS.

A programming model for processing large datasets in parallel across a cluster via map and reduce phases; requires working knowledge of its execution model, partitioning, shuffle step, and fault tolerance via task re-execution.

Reusable solutions to common software architecture problems such as observer, factory, and singleton; requires working knowledge of when and why to apply specific patterns in object-oriented and distributed systems.

The formal rules assigning types to program expressions to detect errors at compile time; requires working knowledge of static vs. dynamic typing, type inference, parametric polymorphism, and type soundness.

L4.brief_rationale: The impossibility result stating a distributed data store cannot simultaneously guarantee consistency, availability, and partition tolerance; requires deep knowledge of its formal proof, practical implications for system design, and the PACELC extension.

A family of consensus protocols for achieving agreement among distributed nodes despite failures; requires deep knowledge of proposer-acceptor-learner roles, multi-Paxos, and its correctness guarantees under asynchronous networks.

Protocols ensuring consistency of shared data across multiple processor caches in multiprocessor systems; requires deep knowledge of MESI protocol variants, snooping vs. directory-based schemes, and their performance implications.

Processor technique executing instructions based on operand availability rather than program order to maximize throughput; requires deep knowledge of Tomasulo's algorithm, reservation stations, reorder buffers, and speculative execution.

A database recovery technique requiring all modifications be recorded in a log before being applied to the database; requires deep knowledge of ARIES recovery, log sequence numbers, checkpointing, and crash recovery guarantees.

A concurrency control mechanism using atomic memory transactions as an alternative to lock-based synchronization; requires deep knowledge of optimistic concurrency, conflict detection, retry semantics, and composability advantages over lock-based approaches.

A compiler infrastructure providing a language-independent intermediate representation and modular optimization framework; requires deep knowledge of SSA form, LLVM IR, pass management, and how frontends and backends plug into the architecture.

A class of hardware vulnerabilities exploiting speculative execution to leak sensitive data across process boundaries; requires deep knowledge of branch prediction, cache side channels, and the microarchitectural mechanisms enabling transient execution attacks.

The ability of a distributed system to reach consensus despite arbitrary (potentially malicious) failures of some components; requires deep knowledge of the Byzantine Generals Problem, PBFT, and the 3f+1 bound.

Data structures that can be replicated across distributed nodes and merged without coordination while guaranteeing eventual consistency; requires deep knowledge of state-based vs. operation-based CRDTs, lattice theory, and their mathematical convergence guarantees.

Formal specifications defining the order in which memory operations become visible to processors; requires deep knowledge of sequential consistency, relaxed memory models (TSO, PSO), memory barriers, and the happens-before relation.

The process of selecting the most efficient execution plan for a database query from among many alternatives; requires deep knowledge of cost estimation, join ordering, selectivity estimation, and the Volcano/Cascades optimization framework.
